entry.title: Coco
entry.content:
Coco

Characters

Miguel Rivera

A smart and brave boy who was born in a shoemaker family. The whole family banned music while Miguel wanted to be an accomplished musician just like his great-great-grandfather. Along the way of chasing his dream, Miguel accidentally traveled the Land of the Dead and met the spirits of his families. A fantastic adventure began.

Hector

A trickster who disguised himself as a famous artist. He was actually a kind and poor young man. He left his hometown and abandoned his family for his dream so that he was forgotten by his family and was going to disappear in the Land of the Dead. After meeting Miguel, he helped him a lot and encouraged Miguel by his humor.

Ernesto de la Cruz

A welcomed musician. Each year on DÃ­a de los Muertos, he would put on a show to mark the end of the festival. However, there were many dirty secrets hidden behind his success.

Coco

Miguelâ€™s great-grandmother. She was an old lady who couldnâ€™t remember many things any more. She missed her father and her childhood when the whole family often sang beautiful songs together. Finally, with the help of Miguel, she remembered her father again and left the Land of the Living happily.

Chapter 1

Leaving the family home behind, Miguel breathed the crisp air of another sunny morning in Santa Cecilia.

  • crisp /krÉªsp/: adjective (HARD) hard enough to be broken easily

As he headed into town with his shoeshine box, he passed a woman sweeping a stoop.

  • shoeshine /ËˆÊƒuËËŒÊƒaÉªn/: n
    • the act or an instance of polishing a pair of shoes
    1. the appearance or shiny surface of polished shoes
  • stoop /stuËp/: noun (STEPS) to bend the top half of the body forward and down:
    The doorway was so low that we had to stoop to go through it.
    Something fell out of her coat pocket and she stooped down and picked it up.

She waved.

â€œHola, Miguel!â€

  • hola : informal. ï¼ˆSpanishï¼‰hello

â€œHola.â€ Miguel waved back.

Closer to town, Miguel smiled at a lone guitar player plucking away at a song.

  • pluck /plÊŒk/: verb (REMOVE) to pull something, especially with a sudden movement, in order to remove it:
    Caged birds sometimes pluck out their breast feathers.
    He plucked the letter from/out of my hand, and ran off with it.
    Do you pluck your eyebrows (= remove some of the hairs from them to give them a better shape)?

The farther in Miguel went, the more music fâ€Šilled the air.

  • farther /ËˆfÉ‘Ër.Ã°Éš/: adverb comparative of far : to a greater distance:
    How much farther is it to the airport?
    The fogâ€™s so thick, I canâ€™t see farther than about ten feet.

Church bells chimed in harmony. A band played an upbeat tune. A radio blared a swift cumbia rhythm.

Miguel soaked it all in.

He couldnâ€™t help tapping out a beat on a table covered with brightly colored wooden animal figurines.

As Miguel rushed past another stand with pastries for sale, he grabbed a pan dulce and tossed the vendor a coin.

Smelling the sweet bread, Miguelâ€™s canine sidekick, Dante, sidled up to him.

Miguel tore off a piece of the bread and Dante chomped it down.

Everywhere Miguel looked, people were preparing for their loved ones to return from the Land of the Dead by hanging colorful papel picado and laying marigold petals at their doorways.

As usual, Mariachi Plaza was full of musicians strolling around, waiting for their chance to serenade a couple or a family with a love song or a classic corrido.

Soon a tour group gathered around a large statue of a mariachi player in the center of the plaza.

â€œAnd right here, in this very plaza, the young Ernesto de la Cruz took his fâ€Širst steps toward becoming the most beloved singer in Mexican history,â€ said the guide.

Everyone in the group nodded, familiar with the legendary musician and singer.

Along with the tourists, Miguel gazed up at the statue.

Heâ€™d seen it a hundred times, but it always inspired him.

After a moment, Miguel found a spot in the plaza and pulled out his shoeshine box.

A mariachi plopped down for a shine.

Miguel knew the mariachi would enjoy this story.

After all, everyone loved Ernesto.

â€œHe started out a total nobody from Santa Cecilia, like me,â€ said Miguel.

â€œBut when he played music, he made people fall in love with him. He starred in movies. He had the coolest guitar. He could fâ€Šly!â€

Miguel had seen that special effect in some old fâ€Šilm clips.

â€œAnd he wrote the best songs! But my all-time favorite? Itâ€™sâ€”â€œ

Miguel gestured to some musicians nearby, who were playing â€œRemember Me,â€ Ernestoâ€™s biggest hit.

â€œHe lived the kind of life you dream about. Until 1942, when he was crushed by a giant bell.â€

The mariachi looked pointedly at his shoes, which Miguel was only halfheartedly shining.

Ignoring the musician, Miguel shrugged off Ernestoâ€™s unfortunate death.

â€œI wanna be just like him. Sometimes I look at Ernesto and I get this feeling, like weâ€™re connected somehow. Like if he could play music, maybe someday I can, too.â€

Miguel sighed. â€œIf it wasnâ€™t for my family.â€

â€œAy-yi-yi, muchacho,â€ said the mariachi, snapping Miguel out of his story.

â€œHuh?â€ said Miguel.

â€œI asked for a shoeshine, not your life story,â€ replied the mariachi.

â€œOh, yeah, sorry.â€ Miguel lowered his head and polished the manâ€™s shoe.

As he worked, the mariachi casually plucked at his guitar strings.

â€œI just canâ€™t really talk about any of this at home, soâ€”â€œ

â€œLook, if I were you? Iâ€™d march right up to my family and say, â€˜Hey! Iâ€™m a musician. Deal with itâ€™. â€œ

â€œI could never say that.â€

â€œYou ARE a musician, no?â€

â€œI donâ€™t know. I mean, I only really play for myselfâ€”â€œ

â€œAhh!â€ the mariachi howled.

â€œDid Ernesto de la Cruz become the worldâ€™s best musician by hiding his sweet, sweet skills? No! He walked out onto that plaza and he played out loud!â€

The mariachi pointed to the gazebo, where a giant canvas that read talent show was being unfurled.

â€œAh! Mira, mira! Theyâ€™re setting up for tonight. The music competition for DÃ­a de los Muertos. You wanna be like your hero? You should sign up!â€

â€œUh-uhâ€”my family would freak,â€ Miguel said.

â€œLook, if youâ€™re too scared, then, well, have fun making shoes.â€

The mariachi shrugged.

â€œCâ€™mon, what did Ernesto de la Cruz always say?â€

â€œâ€˜Seize your momentâ€™?â€ Miguel said.

The mariachi looked Miguel over and then offered him his guitar.

â€œShow me what you got, muchacho. Iâ€™ll be your fâ€Širst audience.â€

Miguelâ€™s eyebrows rose.

The mariachi really wanted to hear him play?

He glanced down the street to make sure the coast was clear of any family members.

He reached for the guitar.

Once it was cradled in his arms, Miguel spread his fâ€Šingers across the strings, anticipating his chord, andâ€” â€œMiguel!â€ a familiar voice yelled.

Miguel gasped and threw the guitar back into the mariachiâ€™s lap.

Abuelita marched toward him.

TÃ­o Berto and Prima Rosa followed close behind with supplies from the market.

â€œAbuelita!â€ Miguel exclaimed.

â€œWhat are you doing here?â€ she asked.

â€œUm. . . uh. . . ,â€ Miguel stammered as he quickly packed away his shine rag and polishes.

Abuelita didnâ€™t wait for Miguelâ€™s answer.

She barreled up to the mariachi and struck him with her shoe.

â€œYou leave my grandson alone!â€

â€œDoÃ±a, pleaseâ€”I was just getting a shine!â€

â€œI know your tricks, mariachi!â€ She glared at Miguel. â€œWhat did he say to you?â€

â€œHe was just showing me his guitar,â€ Miguel said sheepishly.

His family gasped.

â€œShame on you!â€ TÃ­o Berto barked at the mariachi.

Abuelitaâ€™s shoe was aimed directly at the area between the musicianâ€™s eyes.

â€œMy grandson is a sweet little angelito querido cielitoâ€”he wants no part of your music, mariachi! You keep away from him!â€ she threatened.

Miguel wasnâ€™t so sure he was the sweet little angel from heaven sheâ€™d described, but he wasnâ€™t going to argue when she was gripping her shoe like that.

The mariachi scampered away, pulling on his hat before leaving.

Miguel watched apologetically over his abuelitaâ€™s shoulder.

â€œAy, pobrecito!â€

Abuelita pulled her grandson protectively to her bosom.

â€œEstÃ¡s bien, mâ€™ijo?â€ Miguel gasped for air.

â€œYou know better than to be here in this place! You will come home. Now!â€ she ordered, and turned away from the plaza.

Miguel sighed and gathered his shine box.

He spotted a plaza talent-show fâ€Šlyer on the ground.

Behind his abuelitaâ€™s back, he snatched it up and put it in his pocket.

Hello, Iâ€™m David Harper with the BBC News.The heads of Brazilâ€™s army, navy and air force have resigned as President Jair Bolsonaro struggles to contain a crisis over his leadership. Mr. Bolsonaro was forced to reshuffle his cabinet on Monday, replacing the Defense and Foreign ministers. Here is our correspondent Will Grant.

The three men, General Edson Leal Pujol, Admiral Ilques Barbosa and Lieutenant-Brigadier Antonio Carlos Bermudes are furious over the way in which the previous Defense Minister was forced out. In what was believed to have been a fiery and hostile first meeting with his replacement, a Bolsonaro loyalist called Braga Netto, the military chiefs tended their resignations. It all amounts to the biggest political crisis President Bolsonaro has experienced since coming to office. Combined with his mismanagement of the coronavirus pandemic, the pressure on the right-wing leader has ramped up significantly in recent weeks.

The German Chancellor Angela Merkel has agreed to suspend the use of the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine for the under-60s after the countryâ€™s vaccine committee said it had received reports of 31 cases of a rare type of blood clot, among more than 2.7 million people who received the jab. Jenny Hill is in Berlin. Angela Merkel said the decision was about trust, in which she said be wrong to sweep the very rare, but very serious cases under the carpet. Even so, the development presents a problem for the Chancellor whoâ€™s under pressure to speed up a sluggish vaccination program as case numbers rise.

Mrs. Merkel acknowledged there would now be public concern around the vaccine, the development which may worry on the governments. The world Health Organization says that the vaccine is safe and the European Medicines Agency, which is still investigating the cases, has insisted that the benefits of the vaccine far outweigh the very low risks.

A judge in New York has sentenced the brother of the Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez to life in prison for trafficking drugs and possessing machine guns. Our correspondent Nada Twafic has this report. For more than a decade, Tony Hernandez trafficked more than 185 tons of cocaine into the United States by plane, boat and submarine. Some of the illegal drugs were apparently labeled with his initials.

US attorney said the former congressman used the proceeds in part to influence three presidential elections. His brother Juan Orlando Hernandez established himself as a champion in the fight against drugs, but prosecutors labeled him as a coconspirator who took millions of dollars in bribes from drug lords, including El Chapol. He has not been formally charged in the United States. Nada Twafic reporting.

This is the latest world news from the BBC.

Chile Closing Its Border in April

ã€ŒBBC World Newsã€

Hello, Iâ€™m Chris Barrow with the BBC News.

The BBC has obtained a series of disturbing videos that appear to show the killing of unarmed civilians in Ethiopiaâ€™s northern Tigray region by people wearing Ethiopian army uniforms. The gunmen are heard speaking Amharic, Ethiopiaâ€™s official language, while the victims speak Tigrinya. Laetitia Bader is the Horn of Africa director for Human Rights Watch.Since the beginning of the conflict in the Tigray region, weâ€™ve documented a whole magnitude of very serious abuses including extrajudicial executions by Ethiopian government forces and their allies. And this is absolutely an incident which would require further investigation, because what we are seeing here in the video could amount to war crimes.In response, the Ethiopian government has said social media posts and claims cannot be taken as evidence. The United Nations is investigating numerous allegations of atrocities.

The United Nationsâ€™ resident coordinator in Myanmar has told the BBC he fears the security situation in the country could get much worse. Andrew Kirkwood said evidence suggested the security forces were committed to the deliberate, coordinated and widespread use of lethal force.This week, I think itâ€™s important to emphasize was the bloodiest week since the coup.So far, weâ€™ve confirmed 538 people killed by the security forces and thousands more have been injured. Most of those in Yangon or Yangon and Mandalay, the two biggest cities. In fact, one in seven of all of those deaths are children under the age of 18 and some of them as young as five. And I think itâ€™s also emphasizing the 90% of all of those deaths are from gunshots and the majority of those were bullets to the head, often by snipers and in broad daylight.

Politicians from all sides of the Dutch parliament have accused Mark Rutte of lying as the House debates a motion of no confidence in the long serving Prime Minister. The crisis arose on Thursday after documents showed that in coalition talks, Mr. Rutte had discussed a possible new job for a prominent member of parliament who had been critical of his previous cabinet. Mr. Rutte had previously said he did not do so.

Chile has closed its border for the month of April as it seeks to slow the spread of coronavirus. Health officials said a second wave had left hospitals close to collapse. Jane Chambers reports from Santiago.Only returning residents will be allowed into Chile for the next month. And most of the country is in full lockdown. The Chilean government hopes these measures will slow down the rate of infection. On Thursday, they announced the highest number of cases in one day for the whole of the pandemic. Around 35% of the population have already received their jab. But critics say that the government opened schools, malls and restaurants too early.

This has led to a spike in cases.

COVID-19 in Mexico Climbs 60% Higher, Ranking 2nd in the Global List

Hello, Iâ€™m Justine Greene with the BBC News. The government of Mozambique says Islamist militants who began attacking the town of Palma on Wednesday have killed dozens of people.Thousands have fled the assault in the northern province of Cabo Delgado. A Defense Department spokesman Omar Saranga denied the military response had been slow. Hereâ€™s our Africa correspondent Catherine Byaruhanga.

After days of silence thatâ€™s left many Mozambicans anxious, state security forces shed some light on the events unfolding in Palma. Mr. Omar Saranga said at least seven people were killed when their convoy came under fire as they tried to escape from the town.

The family of a South African man Adrian Nell confirmed he died in the ambush. There has been criticism of the armyâ€™s response to the attack in Palma.

Survivorsâ€™ talk of having to fend for themselves as they sought safety. New figures show the number of deaths linked to COVID-19 in Mexico is 60% higher than previously thought. 320,000 Mexicans are thought to have died with the disease. Our correspondent Will Grant reports.

Having failed to produce excess death data for some time, a government report concluded that a little under 300,000 people died from the virus since the pandemic began until mid-February.

Combined with those who have since died from the illness, Mexico would be placed above Brazil and only behind the United States in the global list of COVID related deaths, despite having a far smaller population than both countries.

In part, the difficulty of obtaining a completely clear picture of the problem in Mexico comes from its low rate of testing. It is also believed that given the shortage of ICU beds in many states, a large number of people have died at home.

Mexico and Guatemala have announced a joint operation to deploy hundreds of troops and police along their border to prevent migrants from traveling North towards the United States. The authorities say that they are particularly concerned about the growing number of children and teenagers traveling without their parents in migrant caravans.

The German Chancellor Angela Merkel has urged the countryâ€™s regional leaders to abide by a deal to impose tougher coronavirus restrictions as a third wave of infections gathers pace. Damien McGuinness reports.

Germanyâ€™s regional governments had agreed to an emergency break, meaning more lockdown restrictions if infection rates rise over a certain level. In much of Germany that rise has now happened, but some regional leaders are still not using that emergency break. Thatâ€™s an infringement of the agreement, Mrs. Merkel said.

The Chancellor also criticized pilot schemes in some parts of the country aimed at opening everything up by requiring people to have a negative test on the day.

1-1-1 The Boy Who Lived å¤§éš¾ä¸æ­»çš„ç”·å­©

Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much. They were the last people youâ€™d expect to be involved in anything strange or mysterious, because they just didnâ€™t hold with(ç›¸ä¿¡) such nonsense(æ­ªé—¨é‚ªé“).

Dursleyä¸€å®¶éƒ½å¾ˆè§„çŸ©ï¼Œä¸ç›¸ä¿¡å¥‡æ€ªçš„äº‹ã€‚

Mr. Dursley was the director(ä¸»ç®¡) of a firm called Grunnings, which made drills(é’»å¤´) . Dursleyå…ˆç”ŸçŸ­è„–å­å¤§èƒ¡å­ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€å®¶é’»æœºå‚çš„ä¸»ç®¡ï¼Œå¤«äººé‡‘å‘ç¢§çœ¼ï¼Œå–œæ¬¢å·çª¥é‚»é‡Œã€‚æººçˆ±å­©å­Dudleyã€‚

The Dursleys had everything they wanted, but they also had a secret, and their greatest fear was that somebody would discover it.

They didnâ€™t think they could bear(æ‰¿å—) it if anyone found out about the Potters. Mrs. Potter was Mrs. Dursleyâ€™s sister, but they hadnâ€™t met for several years; in fact, Mrs. Dursley pretended she didnâ€™t have a sister, because her sister and her good-for-nothing husband were as unDursleyish(å’ŒDursleyä¸€å®¶å®Œå…¨ä¸åŒ) as it was possible to be. The Dursleys shuddered(èƒ†æˆ˜å¿ƒæƒŠ) to think what the neighbors would say if the Potters arrived in the street. The Dursleys knew that the Potters had a small son, too, but they had never even seen him. Dursleyå¤«äººæ˜¯Potterå¤«äººçš„å§å§ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯Dursleyä¸€å®¶ä¸å–œæ¬¢Potterä¸€å®¶ã€‚æ›´ä¸æƒ³ä»–ä»¬çš„å„¿å­Dudleyä¸Harry Potter å®æ··ã€‚

When Mr. and Mrs. Dursley woke up on the dull(é˜´æš—çš„,è¿Ÿé’çš„,æ— è¶£çš„), gray Tuesday our story starts, there was nothing about the cloudy sky outside to suggest that strange and mysterious things would soon be happening all over the country. Mr. Dursley hummed(å“¼ç€å°æ›²) as he picked out his most boring tie for work, and Mrs. Dursley gossiped(çµ®çµ®å¨å¨) away happily as she wrestled a screaming Dudley into his high chair.

Dursleyå…ˆç”Ÿå¥½çš„é¢†å¸¦ä¸æˆ´ï¼Œåå¾—æŒ‘ä¸€ä¸ªæœ€ä¸å–œæ¬¢çš„é¢†å¸¦æˆ´ç€å»ä¸Šç­ã€‚

At half past eight, Mr. Dursley picked up his briefcase(å…¬æ–‡åŒ…), pecked(è½»å»,å•„) Mrs. Dursley on the cheek(è„¸é¢Š), and tried to kiss Dudley good-bye but missed, because Dudley was now having a tantrum(å°å­©è€è„¾æ°”) and throwing his cereal(éº¦ç‰‡) at the walls. â€œLittle tyke(å°å­©å­;å°æ·˜æ°”;å°è°ƒçš®é¬¼) ,â€ chortled(å¼€æ€€å¤§ç¬‘) Mr. Dursley as he left the house. It was on the corner of the street that he noticed the first sign of something peculiar â€” a cat reading a map. As Mr. Dursley drove around the corner and up the road, he watched the cat in his mirror. It was now reading the sign that said Privet Drive â€” no, looking at the sign; cats couldnâ€™t read maps or signs. Mr. Dursley gave himself a little shake and put the cat out of his mind. As he drove toward town he thought of nothing except a large order of drills(é’»å¤´) he was hoping to get that day.

å¼—å†œå¤§æ—©ä¸Šæ’è§é¬¼ï¼Œä¸ä¸ä¸ï¼Œæ˜¯æ’è§çŒ«åœ¨è¯»è·¯æ ‡ã€‚

But then it struck Mr. Dursley that this was probably some silly stunt(å™±å¤´) â€” these people were obviously collecting for something . . . yes, that would be it. Mr. Dursley always sat with his back to the window in his office on the ninth floor. If he hadnâ€™t, he might have found it harder to concentrate on drills that morning. He didnâ€™t see the owls swooping past in broad daylight(å…‰å¤©åŒ–æ—¥), though people down in the street did; they pointed and gazed open-mouthed as owl after owl sped overhead. Most of them had never seen an owl even at nighttime. Mr. Dursley, however, had a perfectly normal, owl-free(æ²¡æœ‰å—åˆ°çŒ«å¤´é¹°å¹²æ‰°) morning. He yelled at five different people. Heâ€™d forgotten all about the people in cloaks until he passed a group of them next to the bakerâ€™s. He eyed them angrily as he passed. He didnâ€™t know why, but they made him uneasy. This bunch were whispering excitedly, too, and he couldnâ€™t see a single collecting tin(å‹Ÿæç®±). çœ‹åˆ°ç©¿æ–—ç¯·çš„äººä»¬åœ¨è®®è®ºå“ˆåˆ©ï¼Œå¾·æ€ç¤¼çš„å¿ƒç†æ´»åŠ¨ç”±ä¸è§£åˆ°æ„¤æ€’ï¼Œåˆ°ä¸ç›¸ä¿¡åˆ°è‡ªæˆ‘éº»ç—¹å’Œè‡ªæˆ‘å®‰æ…°ã€‚éƒ½è¯´æ˜äº†å¾·æ€ç¤¼å†…å¿ƒå¯¹å“ˆåˆ©çš„æŠµè§¦ï¼Œä»¥åŠå¯¹æœ‰å…³å“ˆåˆ©çš„ä¸€åˆ‡æ¶ˆæ¯çš„é˜²å¤‡ã€‚

The Dursleysâ€™ house had four bedrooms: one for Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia, one for visitors (usually Uncle Vernonâ€™s sister, Marge), one where Dudley slept, and one where Dudley kept all the toys and things that wouldnâ€™t fit into his first bedroom. On Friday, no less than twelve letters arrived for Harry. As they couldnâ€™t go through the mail slot they had been pushed under the door, slotted through the sides, and a few even forced through the small window in the downstairs bathroom.

Uncle Vernon stayed at home again. After burning all the letters, he got out a hammer and nails and boarded up the cracks around the front and back doors so no one could go out. He hummed â€œTiptoe Through the Tulipsâ€ as he worked, and jumped at small noises.

Something came whizzing down the kitchen chimney as he spoke and caught him sharply on the back of the head. Next moment, thirty or forty letters came pelting out of the fireplace like bullets. The Dursleys ducked, but Harry leapt into the air trying to catch one â€”

She held up a letter so they could read the green ink address:

Harry made a grab for the letter but Uncle Vernon knocked his hand out of the way. The woman stared.

â€œIâ€™ll take them,â€ said Uncle Vernon, standing up quickly and following her from the dining room.

â€œWouldnâ€™t it be better just to go home, dear?â€ Aunt Petunia suggested timidly, hours later, but Uncle Vernon didnâ€™t seem to hear her. Exactly what he was looking for, none of them knew. He drove them into the middle of a forest, got out, looked around, shook his head, got back in the car, and off they went again. The same thing happened in the middle of a plowed field, halfway across a suspension bridge, and at the top of a multilevel parking garage.

â€œDaddyâ€™s gone mad, hasnâ€™t he?â€ Dudley asked Aunt Petunia dully late that afternoon. Uncle Vernon had parked at the coast, locked them all inside the car, and disappeared.

It started to rain. Great drops beat on the roof of the car. Dudley sniveled.

â€œItâ€™s Monday,â€ he told his mother. â€œThe Great Humbertoâ€™s on tonight. I want to stay somewhere with a television.â€

Monday. This reminded Harry of something. If it was Monday â€” and you could usually count on Dudley to know the days of the week, because of television â€” then tomorrow, Tuesday, was Harryâ€™s eleventh birthday. Of course, his birthdays were never exactly fun â€” last year, the Dursleys had given him a coat hanger and a pair of Uncle Vernonâ€™s old socks. Still, you werenâ€™t eleven every day.

Uncle Vernon was back and he was smiling. He was also carrying a long, thin package and didnâ€™t answer Aunt Petunia when she asked what heâ€™d bought.

â€œIâ€™ve already got us some rations,â€ said Uncle Vernon, â€œso all aboard!â€

It was freezing in the boat. Icy sea spray and rain crept down their necks and a chilly wind whipped their faces. After what seemed like hours they reached the rock, where Uncle Vernon, slipping and sliding, led the way to the broken-down house.

Aunt Petunia found a few moldy blankets in the second room and made up a bed for Dudley on the moth-eaten sofa. You can keep your bowlers black, Your top hats sleek and tall, For Iâ€™m the Hogwarts Sorting Hat And I can cap them all.

Thereâ€™s nothing hidden in your head The Sorting Hat canâ€™t see, So try me on and I will tell you Where you ought to be.

You might belong in Gryffindor, Where dwell the brave at heart, Their daring, nerve, and chivalry Set Gryffindors apart; You might belong in Hufflepuff, Where they are just and loyal, Those patient Hufflepuffs are true And unafraid of toil; Or yet in wise old Ravenclaw, If youâ€™ve a ready mind, Where those of wit and learning, Will always find their kind; Or perhaps in Slytherin Youâ€™ll make your real friends, Those cunning folk use any means To achieve their ends.

So put me on! Donâ€™t be afraid!

And donâ€™t get in a flap!

Youâ€™re in safe hands (though I have none) For Iâ€™m a Thinking Cap!â€

The whole hall burst into applause as the hat finished its song. It bowed to each of the four tables and then became quite still again.

â€œSo weâ€™ve just got to try on the hat!â€ Ron whispered to Harry. â€œIâ€™ll kill Fred, he was going on about wrestling a troll.â€

Harry smiled weakly. Yes, trying on the hat was a lot better than having to do a spell, but he did wish they could have tried it on without everyone watching. The hat seemed to be asking rather a lot; Harry didnâ€™t feel brave or quick-witted or any of it at the moment. If only the hat had mentioned a House for people who felt a bit queasy, that would have been the one for him.

Professor McGonagall now stepped forward holding a long roll of parchment.

3 Put on the sorting hat æˆ´ä¸Šåˆ†é™¢å¸½

â€œWhen I call your name, you will put on the hat and sit on the stool to be sorted,â€ she said. â€œAbbott, Hannah!â€

A pink-faced girl with blonde pigtails stumbled out of line, put on the hat, which fell right down over her eyes, and sat down. A momentâ€™s pause â€”

Abbott, Hannah æ±‰å¨œ è‰¾åš æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªé¢è‰²çº¢æ¶¦çš„å¥³å­©ï¼Œ

â€œHUFFLEPUFF!â€ shouted the hat.

The table on the right cheered and clapped as Hannah went to sit down at the Hufflepuff table. Harry saw the ghost of the Fat Friar waving merrily at her.

â€œBones, Susan!â€

â€œHUFFLEPUFF!â€ shouted the hat again, and Susan scuttled off to sit next to Hannah.

â€œBoot, Terry!â€

â€œRAVENCLAW!â€

The table second from the left clapped this time; several Ravenclaws stood up to shake hands with Terry as he joined them.

â€œBrocklehurst, Mandyâ€ went to Ravenclaw too, but â€œBrown, Lavenderâ€ became the first new Gryffindor, and the table on the far left exploded with cheers; Harry could see Ronâ€™s twin brothers catcalling.

â€œBulstrode, Millicentâ€ then became a Slytherin. Perhaps it was Harryâ€™s imagination, after all heâ€™d heard about Slytherin, but he thought they looked like an unpleasant lot.

He was starting to feel definitely sick now. He remembered being picked for teams during gym at his old school. He had always been last to be chosen, not because he was no good, but because no one wanted Dudley to think they liked him.

â€œFinch-Fletchley, Justin!â€

â€œHUFFLEPUFF!â€

Sometimes, Harry noticed, the hat shouted out the House at once, but at others it took a little while to decide. â€œFinnigan, Seamus,â€ the sandy-haired boy next to Harry in the line, sat on the stool for almost a whole minute before the hat declared him a Gryffindor.

â€œGranger, Hermione!â€

Hermione almost ran to the stool and jammed the hat eagerly on her head.

â€œGRYFFINDOR!â€ shouted the hat. Ron groaned.

A horrible thought struck Harry, as horrible thoughts always do when youâ€™re very nervous. What if he wasnâ€™t chosen at all? What if he just sat there with the hat over his eyes for ages, until Professor McGonagall jerked it off his head and said there had obviously been a mistake and heâ€™d better get back on the train?

When Neville Longbottom, the boy who kept losing his toad, was called, he fell over on his way to the stool. The hat took a long time to decide with Neville. When it finally shouted, â€œGRYFFINDOR,â€ Neville ran off still wearing it, and had to jog back amid gales of laughter to give it to â€œMacDougal, Morag.â€

Malfoy swaggered forward when his name was called and got his wish at once: the hat had barely touched his head when it screamed, â€œSLYTHERIN!â€

Malfoy went to join his friends Crabbe and Goyle, looking pleased with himself.

There werenâ€™t many people left now.

â€œMoonâ€ . . . , â€œNottâ€ . . . , â€œParkinsonâ€ . . . , then a pair of twin girls, â€œPatilâ€ and â€œPatilâ€ . . . , then â€œPerks, Sally-Anneâ€ . . . , and then, at last â€”

â€œPotter, Harry!â€

4 Harryâ€™s turn è½®åˆ°å“ˆåˆ©äº†

As Harry stepped forward, whispers suddenly broke out like little hissing fires all over the hall.

â€œPotter, did she say?â€

â€œThe Harry Potter?â€

The last thing Harry saw before the hat dropped over his eyes was the hall full of people craning to get a good look at him. Next second he was looking at the black inside of the hat. He waited.

â€œHmm,â€ said a small voice in his ear. â€œDifficult. Very difficult. Plenty of courage, I see. Not a bad mind either. Thereâ€™s talent, oh my goodness, yes â€” and a nice thirst to prove yourself, now thatâ€™s interesting. . . . So where shall I put you?â€

Harry gripped the edges of the stool and thought, Not Slytherin, not Slytherin.

â€œNot Slytherin, eh?â€ said the small voice. â€œAre you sure? You could be great, you know, itâ€™s all here in your head, and Slytherin will help you on the way to greatness, no doubt about that â€” no? Well, if youâ€™re sure â€” better be GRYFFINDOR!â€

Harry heard the hat shout the last word to the whole hall. He took off the hat and walked shakily toward the Gryffindor table. He was so relieved to have been chosen and not put in Slytherin, he hardly noticed that he was getting the loudest cheer yet. Percy the Prefect got up and shook his hand vigorously, while the Weasley twins yelled, â€œWe got Potter! We got Potter!â€ Harry sat down opposite the ghost in the ruff heâ€™d seen earlier. The ghost patted his arm, giving Harry the sudden, horrible feeling heâ€™d just plunged it into a bucket of ice-cold water.

He could see the High Table properly now. At the end nearest him sat Hagrid, who caught his eye and gave him the thumbs up. Harry grinned back. And there, in the center of the High Table, in a large gold chair, sat Albus Dumbledore. Harry recognized him at once from the card heâ€™d gotten out of the Chocolate Frog on the train. Dumbledoreâ€™s silver hair was the only thing in the whole hall that shone as brightly as the ghosts. Harry spotted Professor Quirrell, too, the nervous young man from the Leaky Cauldron. He was looking very peculiar in a large purple turban.

And now there were only four people left to be sorted. â€œThomas, Dean,â€ a Black boy even taller than Ron, joined Harry at the Gryffindor table. â€œTurpin, Lisa,â€ became a Ravenclaw and then it was Ronâ€™s turn. He was pale green by now. Harry crossed his fingers under the table and a second later the hat had shouted, â€œGRYFFINDOR!â€

Harry clapped loudly with the rest as Ron collapsed into the chair next to him.

â€œWell done, Ron, excellent,â€ said Percy Weasley pompously across Harry as â€œZabini, Blaise,â€ was made a Slytherin. Professor McGonagall rolled up her scroll and took the Sorting Hat away.

Harry looked down at his empty gold plate. He had only just realized how hungry he was. The pumpkin pasties seemed ages ago.

Albus Dumbledore had gotten to his feet. He was beaming at the students, his arms opened wide, as if nothing could have pleased him more than to see them all there.

â€œWelcome!â€ he said. â€œWelcome to a new year at Hogwarts! Before we begin our banquet, I would like to say a few words. And here they are: Nitwit! Blubber! Oddment! Tweak!

â€œThank you!â€

He sat back down. Everybody clapped and cheered. Harry didnâ€™t know whether to laugh or not.

â€œIs he â€” a bit mad?â€ he asked Percy uncertainly.

â€œMad?â€ said Percy airily. â€œHeâ€™s a genius! Best wizard in the world! But he is a bit mad, yes. Potatoes, Harry?â€

5 The banquet æ™šå®´

Harryâ€™s mouth fell open. The dishes in front of him were now piled with food. He had never seen so many things he liked to eat on one table: roast beef, roast chicken, pork chops and lamb chops, sausages, bacon and steak, boiled potatoes, roast potatoes, fries, Yorkshire pudding, peas, carrots, gravy, ketchup, and, for some strange reason, peppermint humbugs.

The Dursleys had never exactly starved Harry, but heâ€™d never been allowed to eat as much as he liked. Dudley had always taken anything that Harry really wanted, even if it made him sick. Harry piled his plate with a bit of everything except the peppermints and began to eat. It was all delicious.

â€œThat does look good,â€ said the ghost in the ruff sadly, watching Harry cut up his steak.

â€œCanâ€™t you â€” ?â€

â€œI havenâ€™t eaten for nearly five hundred years,â€ said the ghost. â€œI donâ€™t need to, of course, but one does miss it. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve in-troduced myself? Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington at your service. Resident ghost of Gryffindor Tower.â€

â€œI know who you are!â€ said Ron suddenly. â€œMy brothers told me about you â€” youâ€™re Nearly Headless Nick!â€

â€œI would prefer you to call me Sir Nicholas de Mimsy â€”â€ the ghost began stiffly, but sandy-haired Seamus Finnigan interrupted.

â€œNearly Headless? How can you be nearly headless?â€

Sir Nicholas looked extremely miffed, as if their little chat wasnâ€™t going at all the way he wanted.

â€œLike this,â€ he said irritably. He seized his left ear and pulled. His whole head swung off his neck and fell onto his shoulder as if it was on a hinge. Someone had obviously tried to behead him, but not done it properly. Looking pleased at the stunned looks on their faces, Nearly Headless Nick flipped his head back onto his neck, coughed, and said, â€œSo â€” new Gryffindors! I hope youâ€™re going to help us win the House Championship this year? Gryffindors have never gone so long without winning. Slytherins have got the cup six years in a row! The Bloody Baronâ€™s becoming almost unbearable â€” heâ€™s the Slytherin ghost.â€

Harry looked over at the Slytherin table and saw a horrible ghost sitting there, with blank staring eyes, a gaunt face, and robes stained with silver blood. He was right next to Malfoy who, Harry was pleased to see, didnâ€™t look too pleased with the seating arrangements.

â€œHow did he get covered in blood?â€ asked Seamus with great interest.

â€œIâ€™ve never asked,â€ said Nearly Headless Nick delicately.

When everyone had eaten as much as they could, the remains of the food faded from the plates, leaving them sparkling clean as before. A moment later the desserts appeared. Blocks of ice cream in every flavor you could think of, apple pies, treacle tarts, chocolate Ã©clairs and jam doughnuts, trifle, strawberries, Jell-O, rice pudding . . .

As Harry helped himself to a treacle tart, the talk turned to their families.

â€œIâ€™m half-and-half,â€ said Seamus. â€œMe dadâ€™s a Muggle. Mom didnâ€™t tell him she was a witch â€™til after they were married. Bit of a nasty shock for him.â€

The others laughed.

â€œWhat about you, Neville?â€ said Ron.

â€œWell, my gran brought me up and sheâ€™s a witch,â€ said Neville, â€œbut the family thought I was all-Muggle for ages. My Great Uncle Algie kept trying to catch me off my guard and force some magic out of me â€” he pushed me off the end of Blackpool pier once, I nearly drowned â€” but nothing happened until I was eight. Great Uncle Algie came round for dinner, and he was hanging me out of an upstairs window by the ankles when my Great Auntie Enid offered him a meringue and he accidentally let go. But I bounced all the way down the garden and into the road. They were all really pleased, Gran was crying, she was so happy. And you should have seen their faces when I got in here â€” they thought I might not be magic enough to come, you see. Great Uncle Algie was so pleased he bought me my toad.â€

On Harryâ€™s other side, Percy Weasley and Hermione were talking about lessons (â€œI do hope they start right away, thereâ€™s so much to learn, Iâ€™m particularly interested in Transfiguration, you know, turning something into something else, of course, itâ€™s supposed to be very difficult â€”â€; â€œYouâ€™ll be starting small, just matches into needles and that sort of thing â€”â€).

Harry, who was starting to feel warm and sleepy, looked up at the High Table again. Hagrid was drinking deeply from his goblet. Professor McGonagall was talking to Professor Dumbledore. Professor Quirrell, in his absurd turban, was talking to a teacher with greasy black hair, a hooked nose, and sallow skin.

It happened very suddenly. The hook-nosed teacher looked past Quirrellâ€™s turban straight into Harryâ€™s eyes â€” and a sharp, hot pain shot across the scar on Harryâ€™s forehead.

â€œOuch!â€ Harry clapped a hand to his head.

â€œWhat is it?â€ asked Percy.

â€œN-nothing.â€

The pain had gone as quickly as it had come. Harder to shake off was the feeling Harry had gotten from the teachers look â€” a feeling that he didnâ€™t like Harry at all.

â€œWhoâ€™s that teacher talking to Professor Quirrell?â€ he asked Percy.

â€œOh, you know Quirrell already, do you? No wonder heâ€™s looking so nervous, thatâ€™s Professor Snape. He teaches Potions, but he doesnâ€™t want to â€” everyone knows heâ€™s after Quirrellâ€™s job. Knows an awful lot about the Dark Arts, Snape.â€

Harry watched Snape for a while, but Snape didnâ€™t look at him again.

At last, the desserts too disappeared, and Professor Dumbledore got to his feet again. The hall fell silent.

â€œAhem â€” just a few more words now that we are all fed and watered. I have a few start-of-term notices to give you.

â€œFirst years should note that the forest on the grounds is forbidden to all pupils. And a few of our older students would do well to remember that as well.â€

Dumbledoreâ€™s twinkling eyes flashed in the direction of the Weasley twins.

â€œI have also been asked by Mr. Filch, the caretaker, to remind you all that no magic should be used between classes in the corridors.

â€œQuidditch trials will be held in the second week of the term. Anyone interested in playing for their House teams should contact Madam Hooch.

â€œAnd finally, I must tell you that this year, the third-floor corridor on the right-hand side is out of bounds to everyone who does not wish to die a very painful death.â€

Harry laughed, but he was one of the few who did.

â€œHeâ€™s not serious?â€ he muttered to Percy.

â€œMust be,â€ said Percy, frowning at Dumbledore. â€œItâ€™s odd, because he usually gives us a reason why weâ€™re not allowed to go somewhere â€” the forestâ€™s full of dangerous beasts, everyone knows that. I do think he might have told us prefects, at least.â€

â€œAnd now, before we go to bed, let us sing the school song!â€ cried Dumbledore. Harry noticed that the other teachersâ€™ smiles had become rather fixed.

Dumbledore gave his wand a little flick, as if he was trying to get a fly off the end, and a long golden ribbon flew out of it, which rose high above the tables and twisted itself, snakelike, into words.

â€œEveryone pick their favorite tune,â€ said Dumbledore, â€œand off we go!â€

And the school bellowed:

â€œHogwarts, Hogwarts, Hoggy Warty Hogwarts, Teach us something please, Whether we be old and bald Or young with scabby knees, Our heads could do with filling With some interesting stuff, For now theyâ€™re bare and full of air, Dead flies and bits of fluff, So teach us things worth knowing, Bring back what weâ€™ve forgot, Just do your best, weâ€™ll do the rest, And learn until our brains all rot.â€

Everybody finished the song at different times. At last, only the Weasley twins were left singing along to a very slow funeral march. Dumbledore conducted their last few lines with his wand and when they had finished, he was one of those who clapped loudest.

â€œAh, music,â€ he said, wiping his eyes. â€œA magic beyond all we do here! And now, bedtime. Off you trot!â€

6 And so to bed å™©æ¢¦

The Gryffindor first years followed Percy through the chattering crowds, out of the Great Hall, and up the marble staircase. Harryâ€™s legs were like lead again, but only because he was so tired and full of food. He was too sleepy even to be surprised that the people in the portraits along the corridors whispered and pointed as they passed, or that twice Percy led them through doorways hidden behind sliding panels and hanging tapestries. They climbed more staircases, yawning and dragging their feet, and Harry was just wondering how much farther they had to go when they came to a sudden halt.

A bundle of walking sticks was floating in midair ahead of them, and as Percy took a step toward them they started throwing themselves at him.

â€œPeeves,â€ Percy whispered to the first years. â€œA poltergeist.â€ He raised his voice, â€œPeeves â€” show yourself.â€

A loud, rude sound, like the air being let out of a balloon, answered.

â€œDo you want me to go to the Bloody Baron?â€

There was a pop, and a little man with wicked, dark eyes and a wide mouth appeared, floating cross-legged in the air, clutching the walking sticks.

â€œOooooooh!â€ he said, with an evil cackle. â€œIckle Firsties! What fun!â€

He swooped suddenly at them. They all ducked.

â€œGo away, Peeves, or the Baronâ€™ll hear about this, I mean it!â€ barked Percy.

Peeves stuck out his tongue and vanished, dropping the walking sticks on Nevilleâ€™s head. They heard him zooming away, rattling coats of armor as he passed.

â€œYou want to watch out for Peeves,â€ said Percy, as they set off again. â€œThe Bloody Baronâ€™s the only one who can control him, he wonâ€™t even listen to us prefects. Here we are.â€

At the very end of the corridor hung a portrait of a very fat woman in a pink silk dress.

â€œPassword?â€ she said.

â€œCaput Draconis,â€ said Percy, and the portrait swung forward to reveal a round hole in the wall. They all scrambled through it Neville needed a leg up â€” and found themselves in the Gryffindor common room, a cozy, round room full of squashy armchairs.

Percy directed the girls through one door to their dormitory and the boys through another. At the top of a spiral staircase â€” they were obviously in one of the towers â€” they found their beds at last: five four-posters hung with deep red, velvet curtains. Their trunks had already been brought up. Too tired to talk much, they pulled on their pajamas and fell into bed.

â€œGreat food, isnâ€™t it?â€ Ron muttered to Harry through the hangings. â€œGet off, Scabbers! Heâ€™s chewing my sheets.â€

Harry was going to ask Ron if heâ€™d had any of the treacle tart, but he fell asleep almost at once.

Perhaps Harry had eaten a bit too much, because he had a very strange dream. He was wearing Professor Quirrellâ€™s turban, which kept talking to him, telling him he must transfer to Slytherin at once, because it was his destiny. Harry told the turban he didnâ€™t want to be in Slytherin; it got heavier and heavier; he tried to pull it off but it tightened painfully â€” and there was Malfoy, laughing at him as he struggled with it â€” then Malfoy turned into the hook-nosed teacher, Snape, whose laugh became high and cold there was a burst of green light and Harry woke, sweating and shaking.

He rolled over and fell asleep again, and when he woke next day, he didnâ€™t remember the dream at all.

English Diary

At First

  • Iâ€™m from China and I plan to write daily to share my life with you and also improve my English skills.

  • I love guitars, cats, and programming. I hope to be your friend.

  • I will copy this into my diary after you help me; if you want to share something with me that makes you happy, please write it down, I will be very happy to write it in my diary.

Live Long and Prosper

LOL

If you are a naive English speaker and you want to practice Chinese and help me practice English you can send an email to me (firstandthen@126.com), or send message on skype (https://join.skype.com/invite/xUPdthI9XQrf),

Diary

I donâ€™t know why I usually write the diary for the past day. I think it might because I need to think a lot about how to express my thoughts. When I write a diary in Chinese, I just â€œsayâ€ without too much consideration. So when I write diary in English, I spend so much time.

But Iâ€™m so lucky that every friend around me spends their time to correct my grammar and talk with me. I have good patience, and I like to talk with others. My friends suggested me becoming a Chinese language teacher the day before yesterday. That might come true, really. I felt a sense of achievement when I taught a friend to say â€œmy name is â€¦, and Iâ€™m from Saudi Arabiaâ€ in Chinese.

July 18, 2021

Sunny

We had a team dinner last night, because our upperclasswoman (Iâ€™m not sure about how to express that word, might be â€œschool-sisterâ€?) was graduated successfully. She teached me a lot skills about how to communicate with others. Our research team is very harmonious and we treat each other like siblings.

July 16, 2021

Rainy to sunny

It has been a long time since I wrote my last diary. There were so many things that happened these days. I went to Beijing last week for my PhD application with my masterâ€™s degree advisor. Itâ€™s not easy applying for a PhD. So we visited many teachers. Fortunately, many teachers appreciated my abilities. I think I have a good chance to be able to study in Beijing.

One of the most significant impressions I got when I stayed in Beijing was how crowded it was. Beijing is one of the most famous cities around the world. There are so many people living in Beijing. Many young people who work or go to school flock to the subway every morning. They didnâ€™t seem familiar with each other, but the crowd pressed together. I was also one of them, I even felt the temperature from the strangers. I forgot when the last time I hugged someone was, but Iâ€™m afraid that I will feel the warmth of people this way in the future.

@Christian Bleischwitz

Hello again, Echo :)

Iâ€™m glad to hear your PhD applications went well. I wish you lots of fun in Beijing if you go there!

Did you get accepted already? Then you have â€œtheâ€ chance to study in Beijing. If what youâ€™re trying to say is that you think your application went well, then you have â€œa chanceâ€ instead. I would say â€œI think I have a (good) chance to be able to study in Beijing.

One little note about the text is the one sentence where you wrote â€œweâ€. Donâ€™t suddenly change the pronoun from singular to plural unless the context makes it clear there is another person involved. Throughout the whole thext, the only person I see who is applying in Beijing is you, so I never learnt who else would be included in â€œweâ€. Without the context, it makes no sense!

Iâ€™m pointing this out because I see a lot of Chinese people make this mistake (probably because pronouns work differently for you, Iâ€™m guessing).

Hi Christian!

Iâ€™m really happy to receive your correction again :). I got that I shouldnâ€™t suddenly change the pronoun. When I wrote â€œwe visited many teachersâ€ because my masterâ€™s degree advisor went to Beijing with me. But I didnâ€™t explain this in my diary, so it made readers confused. I will notice it in my future diary.

And I didnâ€™t get accepted already. I just have a change to take the exam. So I rewrote the sentence to â€œI have a good chanceâ€¦â€.

Hope you hava a nice day!

And Iâ€™m happy to help =)

I read the text again and (I think) itâ€™s good now! Your new version is better, now the change in pronoun makes sense!

Good luck with the exam!!

June 7,2021

Sunny

Today, it is really hot. We bought a mobile air conditioner, but the after-sales department told us that we should wait several days until they have the mounting hardware. So we have to bear the hot weather for now. Christian told me that he went to the bouldering hall yesterday. I know that there is a bouldering hall in the shopping mall near our college, but I have never attempted to go climbing there. I donâ€™t know if climbing is popular in China. I know that I seldom hear my friends say theyâ€™ll go climbing. I guess maybe climbing is popular in some big cities in China, but the city where I live is so small, people usually work out at the gym. Basketball or table tennis is more likely to be the first choice for them.

@Christian Bleischwitz

If you want to use â€œmobile air conditioningâ€, you have to drop the definite article and just say â€œWe bought mobile air conditioningâ€. Otherwise, it will make me think you are talking about a specific machine that you mentioned before. However, the reader lacks the context here, and because of that it ends up sounding incorrect.

If you say you â€œhear [your] friends go climbingâ€, it means that you are somewhere completely else but they are soooo loud while climbing that you can still hear themâ€¦

so thatâ€™s why you need to say you rarely hear them say that theyâ€™ll go climbing.

If your friends go climbing again, why donâ€™t you give it a shot? :) My friend had suggested it more than once but I was kinda scared to go, too. Eventually, I gave in and I was very surprised by how much I liked it. Maybe itâ€™s not your thing, but you have to try to know! I definitely recommend going with friends, though, itâ€™s much more fun that way.

June 6,2021

Sunny

After several days of rest, I resumed my English studies. I need to stay up late as little as possible. Recent experience tells me that if I donâ€™t get enough sleep, my learning efficiency becomes lower, and my ability to memorize things decreases. The loss outweighs the gain.

Tomorrow is the College Entrance Examination, which is vital for most Chinese students. I passed that exam many years before. Even though many years have passed since, I can recall it very well. I was so nervous during the exam. And I really hope the students who will take that exam tomorrow will get a good grade. In China, studying at a good college is really important for the future life. Because a good college means better educational sources, better career opportunities, even wider views.

@Christian Bleischwitz

â€œIf I donâ€™t get enough sleep, my learning efficiency will become lowerâ€ isnâ€™t completely incorrect. I do think that as a general statement, the zero conditional works well here to reinforce that. But your version works as well.

I think by â€œmy memory decreasesâ€ you meant to say that you get worse and learning things by heart. I corrected your text with that meaning in mind. What you wrote, â€œmy memory decreasesâ€, sounds very strange. But more importantly, without context, I would have thought what youâ€™re trying to say is that you lose memories or the ability to remember things at all (the way people with dementia or Alzehimerâ€™s disease might do).

Also watch out for the wrong prepositions that I corrected :)

Today I went to the bouldering hall and now Iâ€™m pretty beat. Is climbing popular in China, too? Itâ€™s become a trend in Europe in the last decade or so.

Hi Christian! Thanks for your correction. Here is my note:

  1. Zero Conditional

    In zero conditional sentences, the tense in both parts of the sentence is the simple present.In zero conditional sentences, we can replace â€œifâ€ with â€œwhenâ€, because both express general truths. The meaning will be unchanged.

    The zero conditional is used to make statements about the real world, and often refers to general truths, such as scientific facts. In these sentences, the time is now or always and the situation is real and possible.

    e.g. If I donâ€™t get enough sleep, my learning efficiency becomes lower.

    If clause (condition) Main clause (result)
    If + simple present simple present
    If this thing happens that thing happens.

  2. â€œthe memory decreasesâ€ vs â€œthe ability to memorize things decreasesâ€

    the memory decreases -> memory loss due to illness

    the ability to memorize things decreases -> canâ€™t remember something

  3. right prepositions

    • study at a good college

    • is important for the future life

Hey again, Echo.

Just a little improvement for your notes:

When the ability to memorize things decreases, you canâ€™t MAKE yourself remember something NEW.

When your memory becomes worse (â€œmemory decreasesâ€ sounds a bit unnatural), you stop being able to remember things that happened in the past well. It doesnâ€™t have to be from illness, it is said that peopleâ€™s memory declines (get worse) as they age in general.

Instead of decrease, use the word â€œdeclineâ€ in this situation! The common collocations in this context may be a bit hard to figure out unless youâ€™ve read about it previously.

June 2, 2021

Rainy

There was heavy rain yesterday. I stayed in the laboratory and met with friends online. And yesterday was also the Childrenâ€™s Day. A strange phenomenon has appeared these years that even adults celebrate the Childrenâ€™s Day. Many of my friends received money from their parents and received candies from their friends. Many of my friends usually call themselves a baby. All grownups were once children, and I think they never forget that. And a new policy has been introduced in China. Families can have a third child now.

@Christian Bleischwitz

You start a lot of sentences with â€œAndâ€, Echo. In colloquial texts like chat messages or in informal speech, this is absolutely fine. But if you want to practice you writing, I think you should try to get rid of this habit. In a formal text, you should use other conjunctions that go at the start of a sentence, because â€œandâ€ should only really be used to connect two sentences together, not to start one.

I know you realized that with â€œthese daysâ€ you should use the simple present, and â€œthese yearsâ€ really does work in a similar way. However, here I would definitely suggest usage of the present perfect. The appearance of a strange phenomenon is not a general statement about â€œthese yearsâ€, because it is a development. The word â€œappearâ€ already has this written all over it. Because a phenomenon can only start to appear once, you canâ€™t make this a general statement.

You could say â€œThese years, even adults celebrate Childrenâ€™s Dayâ€, this sentence works perfectly fine in simple present!

But with â€œEven adults have started to celebrateâ€, youâ€™d need to use the present perfect, and your sentence with â€œappearâ€ has the same problem.

Hope this helps!

Hi Christian! Thanks for your suggestion. I noticed that I use the word â€œandâ€ too much. I will use â€œandâ€ beside two sentences with logical connection.

I learnt that I prefer to use the present perfect because the â€œappearâ€ already happened, but â€œcelebrateâ€ have not this question.

May 31, 2021

Sunny

These days, I spend almost my whole time studying English. And recently, I felt that I didnâ€™t have enough time, so I stopped my running plan and my guitar training. I did so many IELTS exercises that I dreamed about the exam almost every day. But one thing abruptly came to my mind yesterday, which was that I need to have some balance.

Wow, so it really means Oreo! I would never have guessed from the characters. I guess the word was made up to sound like Oreo because å¥¥ and åˆ© mean completely unrelated things, I think?

About your question, there is a problem! For this, you should read up on â€œconditional sentencesâ€. I will try to explain it briefly:

In your case, there are two ways to form this sentence:

â€œIf he likes you, he will [â€¦]â€ (first conditional, you think this is realistic)

or

â€œIf he liked you, he would [â€¦]â€ (second conditional, you think this is unrealistic/unlikely)

With these types of sentences, the tenses in both the if-clause (the part of the sentence that starts with if) and the main clause (the other part of the sentences) are set in stone. You donâ€™t change them and you donâ€™t mix them!

So â€œIf he liked you, he will [â€¦]â€ is not correct.

I know why it sounds strange to say â€œIf he likedâ€, because it makes you think itâ€™s in the past. But this â€œif you likedâ€ is not in the past! It means â€œIf he likes you (right now)â€, except you donâ€™t think itâ€™s realistic that will happen.

When talking about the past, the sentence would be â€œIf he had liked youâ€.

April 26, 2021

Sunny

I had a tummy stomachache the day before yesterday. So I had a rest yesterday.

In the following days, Iâ€™d want to tell some stories about my lovely cats. Hope you will like them.

Jomi(å•¾å’ª) was given to a girl as an indulging present by a boy when he was solely a kitten. After the girl turned him down, however, my friend took Jomi in and sheltered him. When Jomi was about two years old, my friend could not keep him further due to his work. Another lady then adopted Jomi. A year had passed, the nice lady became pregnant. She did not feel comfortable keeping the cat during her pregnancy. Fortunately, I was able to take Jomi over and provide him a cozy home. Love you, Jomi!

@Christian Bleischwitz

In the first sentence, I think you might have wanted to say:

â€œI had a tummy ache the night before yesterdayâ€?

The way you wrote it, it sounds like you had a tummy ache the day before yesterdayâ€™s night. The day before yesterday and the day before yesterdayâ€™s night are the same, though.

Also, as I understood it, the lady adopted Jomi and then became pregnant a year later, right? Then you canâ€™t say â€œobtaining the cat during her pregnancyâ€, because she already had Jomi before. â€œTo obtainâ€ is the same as â€œto getâ€, the action of receiving and not the same as â€œto haveâ€.

Very good text otherwise, few mistakes! =)

April 24, 2021

Overcast to sunny

I donâ€™t think my life is filled with too much happiness, but I have many people who care about me.

My friend told me that she would send me flowers last night, I was so happy I couldnâ€™t sleep all night! I just want to have an easy life, you know? A simple life without too much trouble, even though thatâ€™s hard to achieve.

I helped my friend install a software at noon that can automatically reply to â€œbullet commentsâ€ in bilibili. She thanked me with a cup of fruit milk tea. When I received the milk tea, the sun broke through the clouds and shone down on me that made me feel warm. That might have been a great life experience.

I wish you a happier life than I have.

@Felix Zhou

I see you are improving! Great job!
Not everyone can become heros, most people are ordinary, they cheer for the heros.
You have a great life. You have a job, wonderful friends and many things! Appreciate what you have and allways be thankful for what you have!

@Christian Bleischwitz

Hello again Echo :)

Itâ€™s â€œto help somebody do somethingâ€, without another â€œtoâ€. Watch out for that.

I donâ€™t quite understand what you were trying to say with â€œWe shared what we haveâ€? Are you talking about sharing experiences or sharing possessions? Itâ€™s hard to correct for me without knowing, so please let me know. :D

Technically itâ€™s not incorrect to say â€œThe sun broke through the clouds, and the sun shone down on me.â€, but it sounds extremely unnatural. With short sentences like this that have the same subject, you shouldnâ€™t repeat it again.

Whether or not you set the comma is up to you. However, when connecting two clauses with the same subject, it is generally advised to set no comma.

I hope this helps!

On the 25th, it was very sunny in Germany. I went outside with my friend in the afternoon and we played frisbee together! Afterwards we relaxed in the sun and I ate a lot of blueberries. That really put my mind at ease. I wish you a lot of happy days like that! :D

Iâ€™m so happy to receive your words.

Let me take an example to explain the meaning of â€œWe shared what we haveâ€. I can make computer programs, and one of my friends can draw very well. So I helped him to solve the problem with computer, and he sent me some nice pictures he draw. Thatâ€™s what I want to say, we shared the skills what we have, and then, we became good friends.

Your words really help me a lot! Thanks again!

Okay, I see what you were trying to say now! You can still use â€œshareâ€ here, but you have to say â€œto share a skill with somebodyâ€. So in your text, it should say: â€œWe shared our skills with each other, [â€¦]â€.

If you only say â€œWe shared our skills and became friendsâ€, I think everyone would understand what you mean from the context. However, this sentence doesnâ€™t say anything about who you shared your skills with. So this could also mean you both shared your skills with a bunch of other people because you were both part of the same club, and then you became friends that way. This is why you need the â€œwith each otherâ€ for it to sound natural and be clear.

Iâ€™m glad my feedback is useful, youâ€™re very welcome!

April 23, 2021

Overcast

Yesterday, I watched a TED video called â€œWhat Happened When We All Stoppedâ€, the words paired with the song made me feel very inspired. Itâ€™s time to once again get closer to mother nature. With more trees and less buildings, we might have a better future.

Last night, I made a new friend called CÃ©sar (/sÉªËˆzÉ›/). This was the first time I have communicated with a foreigner. I was so nervous and not sure what to say so I just listened for a long time. But cÃ©sar noticed me, and greeted me, and gave me have the chance to talk. He is kind because he tried to slow his speed down in order to let me understand his wordsâ€™ meaning.

I hope you and I have a good day!

@Linux#5072

The original is good already. Itâ€™s just some idiomatic stuff.

I also remember when I first talked to people online, it was quite scary and I was stuttering a lot, but after some time, it becomes more natural and easy. I also hope that I donâ€™t talk too fast^ ^ Have a good day!

@Christian Bleischwitz

Hey again Echo! Iâ€™m very happy to hear you made a new friend from a different place :) I think itâ€™s very important to talk to people from different cultures to broaden your horizons. Overcoming the language barrier can be hard, but itâ€™s worth it. Iâ€™m sure if you keep talking to foreigners a lot, youâ€™ll improve at speaking English very quickly!

About your text, you should again be careful not to swap between tenses on accident. If you are talking about events in the past, everything needs to be in simple past. Sometimes you might want to use present perfect or past perfect. But donâ€™t go back to simple present unless:

a) you are no longer talking about the past

or

b) are just stating a general rule.

In your last sentence, â€œhe intended to slow his speed downâ€ sounds like he did not really slow down his speed. This would mean he only tried, but could not do it. So instead itâ€™s better to just say â€œhe tried to slow downâ€ or â€œslowed down his speech for meâ€.

I wish you and me both a good day, too! :D

April 22, 2021

Light rain

Yesterday, my friend went to the hospital to be vaccinated, and passed by some houses with gardens. There were so many flowers in the garden that I could not name them. When she went back to the terrace, she mumbled with uncontrollable excitement, â€œFlowers are blooming! Flowers are blooming!â€.

Last night, I dreamt that I found a big house with four floors. The landlord said it can hold more than ten people. There was a beautiful garden on the second floor, with a shelf containing a lots of lovely decorations. There was a wall of books on the third floor. On the top floor, there was a terrace where everyone could see the sea. Some bluish violet jellyfishes filled the sea.

@Cherry

Really lovely!

@Christian Bleischwitz

Hello again Echo :)

Overall, this was a very good text! You donâ€™t make a lot of mistakes. Your dream sounds very fun. I would tell you about mine, but I already forgot itâ€¦

I also have some comments that might help you. They may be a bit hard to understand, but I hope they will be useful anyway. I wish I could explain in Chinese, but sadly I canâ€™t! :(

In the first sentence, you need a place or the sentence will sound incorrect. If you say â€œShe went to do Xâ€, a native speaker will ask themselves â€œWhere did she go?â€. The sentence sounds incomplete.

â€œto have a vaccinationâ€ gets the meaning across, but to put this correctly, you need to use the passive. (She was vaccinated = to be vaccinated)

If you do not know how to use the passive yet, you can also say â€œShe got a vaccination yesterdayâ€ (Itâ€™s informal speech though).

â€œ[â€¦] â€œFlowers are blooming! Flowers are blooming!â€, she mumbled with [â€¦]â€ is how to put the verb after the direct speech. In this case, you need a comma (,) and not a full stop (.) . Itâ€™s still the same sentence.

However, you can only say this if you drop the subordinate clause (â€œWhen she went back to the terrace,â€). With this clause before the rest of the sentence, it sounds very strange if you donâ€™t put the verb before the direct speech.

When using indirect speech, watch out for auxiliary verbs must, can, may, etc., because they will change.

can -> could

may -> might

must -> have to

So: The landlord said â€œIt can hold up to ten people.â€

-> The landlord said it could hold up to ten people.

Both â€œcontaining lots ofâ€ and â€œcontaining a lot ofâ€ are okay, but not â€œa lotsâ€ because lots is plural and doesnâ€™t need an article. â€œa lot ofâ€ is already spoken language, but â€œlotsâ€ is even more informal.

Since your dream is over now when you tell the story, you should put everything in it in simple past and not simple present. Watch out not to swap between tenses on accident!

April 21, 2021

Cloudy to light rain

I bought a lovely new diary, and I also made a plan to write in my English diary. Iâ€™m afraid I have poor English, even though I read some English books and songs. But I want to give it a try. I ate shredded chicken noodles tonight, I love it so much. I wish you could have a taste. I also ordered a milk tea with fruit, but I had to wait for a long time.

@Christian Bleischwitz

Hey again Echo!

Maybe you were confused here:

â€œIâ€™m afraid of my poor Englishâ€ = I am scared = My English is scary

(I donâ€™t think your English is scary hahaha)

â€œIâ€™m afraid my English is poorâ€ = â€œI am sorry, but my English is poorâ€ or â€œI am not happy about it, but my English is poorâ€

I think your diary is a very good idea :) I hope you will post regularly! Iâ€™m sure it will help you get better at writing in English. I look forward to giving you feedback and I will tell you if something nice happens to me, too. Today, I will watch a movie with my friends!

@blue_beetle

You like Star Trek?

Do you watch the old Star Trek, or the new movies? Spock is my favorite too.

I know the Star Trek tv series, they wrote a lot of official books of them, so you might want to read some to practice English.

@Felix Zhou

Great lovely diary! Donâ€™t stop doing it!

â€œCan we buy all this in London?â€ Harry wondered aloud.

Harry had never been to London before. Although Hagrid seemed to know where he was going, he was obviously not used to getting there in an ordinary way. He got stuck in the ticket barrier on the Underground, and complained loudly that the seats were too small and the trains too slow.

â€œI donâ€™t know how the Muggles manage without magic,â€ he said as they climbed a broken-down escalator that led up to a bustling road lined with shops.

  • escalator /Ëˆes.kÉ™.leÉª.tÌ¬Éš/: noun [ C ] a set of stairs moved up or down by electric power on which people can stand and be taken from one level of a building to another, especially in stores, railroad stations, and airports:

Hagrid was so huge that he parted the crowd easily; all Harry had to do was keep close behind him.
